0.50.text:
Thank you all for
coming tonight.

It really means a lot to

5.37.text:
So I hope we get to play

9.34.text:
I'm a little bit nervous, but

15.53.text:
I, as most of us,
struggle a little bit

23.58.text:
So I started with this lecture
by looking up on Wikipedia,

31.09.text:
And Wikipedia says,
a cancer survivor

33.49.text:
is a person with cancer of any
type, which is still living.

39.80.text:
And so that's a really
broad definition.

41.64.text:
And there are a lot of
differences about how

46.17.text:
Some think that you
become a survivor

48.35.text:
at the time of your
diagnosis, and other people

51.51.text:
think that you become a survivor
at the end of treatment.

56.17.text:
Some people think that if
you are actively dying,

58.61.text:
you're still a survivor
until you actually pass away.

62.83.text:
And on the other
end of the spectrum,

65.20.text:
we've got some people who have
friends and family members that

70.15.text:
have cancer, and they also
consider themselves survivors.

73.95.text:
Because they understand
that, in some way,

76.12.text:
they are deeply
impacted by cancer,

80.09.text:
and it has changed
their lives, as well.

83.14.text:
So no matter where each
of us is in that category,

88.19.text:
once cancer is found,
there is really

91.05.text:
no other way than turning
into our wholehearted healing

97.11.text:
And really, for the
rest of our lives--

98.95.text:
however long or
short that maybe.

101.57.text:
And that is both a huge gift
and an immense challenge.

106.89.text:
So that's what I want
to talk about tonight.

112.39.text: Oh, before I do that-- go back.

I want to do a little

just so that I can see
a little bit of where

123.07.text: And I promise I'll play, too.

So I want to see who we

with the understanding that

Certain people
show up and there's

135.84.text:
a lot of the

But if we can take a

140.51.text:
see where we are in
our survivorship,

145.29.text:
So if you're willing

147.31.text:
ask you to stand up, if

And I'm not going to

154.27.text:

Just whatever you

So we're in the first year,

And so how about

176.26.text:
Anybody in the-- you can keep

So second year of

This is why I'm

Do we have somewhere

Now I'll tell you just

225.75.text:
I was diagnosed
with breast cancer.

227.51.text:
This is really what

228.97.text:
What Holly said was really

231.77.text: why I'm speaking to you tonight.

233.25.text:
Not because I'm a wilderness

236.42.text:
But simply because
I was diagnosed

242.43.text: And I have a few pics.

That's the obvious "must

261.19.text:
So I have some information
here, on reaching me,

Later on, you can

266.56.text:
I have a business

269.46.text:
that is over there with

272.34.text: your way out, if you'd like to.

275.40.text:
If you take nothing away
tonight from the talk

278.17.text:
but three messages that
are in the next slide,

281.91.text:
I think it's already
a great night.

284.26.text:
So here are the three
messages-- that we are forever

289.68.text:
And it sounds
really simple, but I

291.24.text:
think it's really hard to
validate that for ourselves.

295.39.text:
Everybody wants us to
move on, and so do we.

299.08.text:
But what does moving
on really mean?

300.96.text: So we're going to get into that.

303.09.text:
Number two is that we're on
a lifelong path to healing

307.01.text:
And what that means
is that we don't

310.63.text: have the luxury to take breaks.

313.64.text:
There's a sense that
we are always sitting

317.83.text:
We are always trying,
on all levels,

320.02.text:
to do whatever it takes to
wholeheartedly heal forward.

324.91.text:
Because we don't know if
cancer is going to come back.

329.12.text:
And that makes us a very
particular breed of people.

334.50.text:
And that's probably
the weirdest thing

336.61.text:
that you're going to
hear me say tonight,

338.32.text: and I'll explain it later on.

339.94.text:
Because we don't talk in
our society about elders.

343.41.text: We talk about people being old.

345.73.text:
But the elders is more like
somebody who's initiated,

349.69.text: and who has wisdom to impart.

353.11.text: So we're going to get into that.

360.48.text:
The medical journey
can give the impulse

362.76.text:
to healing with surgery,
and whatever treatments,

366.32.text:
but it's only the beginning of
a really long healing process.

370.82.text:
And once treatment
is complete, we

372.94.text:
are usually left with an
important and sometimes

375.91.text:
overwhelming-feeling
job, to heal our body,

378.84.text:
to heal our mind,
our spirit, our soul,

383.28.text:
and to live this healing
forward into a completely

388.06.text:
You know, territory
of percentages, where

393.45.text:
And as someone said to me once,
it's a very medical definition

397.82.text: to say that it's a 20% chance.

400.21.text:
Because the truth is, if
you have a recurrence,

414.23.text: This is the work I do.

415.69.text:
And these are one of
my favorite trees.

422.58.text:
And sometimes, you don't know
whether they're thriving,

425.38.text:
or whether they're
dying, or whether they're

427.21.text: doing both at the same time.

429.39.text:
But they certainly know
how to hang in there

433.63.text:
So I wanted to bring them
into the show tonight,

437.02.text:
and wanted to talk a
little bit about what

441.05.text:
I do as a wilderness guide,
so it makes any kind of sense.

445.37.text: We take people out into nature.

447.88.text:
And it's usually
people that have

449.78.text:
gone through some pretty
significant change

452.02.text:
in their lives,
and they want to,

454.99.text:
somehow-- they can't be
who they were before.

457.68.text:
So some kind of--
often, a little trauma.

459.90.text: It might have been a divorce.

462.07.text:
It might have been
a loss of somebody.

465.65.text:
And they come to sit out
on the earth by themselves,

469.10.text:
and basically remove
themselves, and go back

473.71.text:
And we put them through
some pretty rough stuff.

479.89.text:
And they're alone, and they
don't have a lot of shelter.

483.95.text:
So they're really out in the
natural world by themselves.

488.32.text: Who does this kind of thing?

490.32.text:
People, usually, that are
going through something

493.80.text: that we call a growth crisis.

496.60.text:
And when I was diagnosed with
cancer, that was my question--

501.13.text: can cancer be a growth crisis?

504.61.text:
Because one of the things that
I realized right away when I got

508.93.text:
diagnosed, is that my
life irrevocably changed.

517.00.text:
It's, like, the moment when life
is over, the way you knew it.

522.01.text:
And you know that you
can never, ever go back.

524.95.text:
You cannot step
back over that line.

528.41.text:
And that's very true for
our ceremony in nature.

530.70.text:
And I found to be very true
in my own cancer journey.

536.31.text:
And so I had this question
for myself-- could cancer

540.17.text:
be an initiation, instead of
just something horrible that

547.92.text:
Could there be any
goodness in it?

550.40.text:
Could it somehow prepare
us for something bigger?

553.60.text:
And so I'm going to look at
what does it mean, initiation.

558.82.text:
I'm going to go with some
quotes from Michael Meade, who

561.15.text:
is a really big name in
wilderness rites of passage.

569.72.text:
that mark a man
or a woman's life

572.17.text:
forever, that pull a person
deeper into life than they

585.25.text:
"Initiatory events are those
that define who a person is,

590.06.text:
or cause some power
to erupt from them,

593.51.text:
or strip everything from
them until all that is left

608.11.text:
"In initiation a
person becomes no one

615.07.text:
Again, does that
apply to cancer?

617.45.text:
It certainly felt
that way, when I

619.07.text:
was at the bottom of my
cauldron, during chemotherapy.

623.10.text:
So life, really, is
initiating us all the time.

626.92.text:
It's just that sometimes
we do certain ceremonies

630.63.text:
to acknowledge it, and other
times life actually comes in.

634.71.text:
So I do think that cancer
really can be a rite of passage,

639.24.text:
and that if we look
at it in that way,

641.17.text:
it can actually be an
invitation to come alive.

647.60.text:
So for that to make a
little bit more sense,

650.08.text:
I'm going to talk about the
three-stage model of rites

653.11.text:
of passage, and to see how that
actually applies to cancer.

660.19.text:
I already spoke a little
bit about severance,

662.38.text:
which is the moment
when life changes.

665.23.text:
And there are other
examples-- which

667.05.text:
is death of a loved one,
marriage, divorce, trauma,

671.78.text:
In our cancer world, it would
be diagnosis-- the moment

675.25.text: that we lose our old life.

678.54.text:
And then there is the
threshold, which is

680.84.text: the time in the liminal world.

683.87.text:
Some call it the hero or
the heroine's journey,

687.43.text:
the in-between place,
the underworld cauldron,

694.40.text:
A place where you really
cannot see in the dark.

698.36.text:
You have to feel
your way through.

700.52.text:
In the cancer world, we
create that with treatment.

707.37.text:
which is reemerging as a new
person in the world-- rebirth,

712.93.text:
sharing, and airing of gifts,
renewal, manifestation,

717.95.text:
marking a new life,
true maturity.

724.02.text:
That's the place where
we all sit today.

727.59.text:
It's the potential
of what we get

731.87.text:
to live into, after
having encountered cancer.

739.53.text:
And it's interesting to
note that survivorship often

745.89.text: seems to be the hardest part.

747.80.text:
Not when we're diagnosed,
but looking back,

751.02.text:
it seems like treatment
was, relatively,

753.74.text:
a time of great support-- the
time where we could just let

756.86.text:
go into it, and just did
our best to get through.

759.66.text:
But that living
it forward ends up

763.14.text:
being the hardest part
of the whole journey.

766.53.text:
And so that's what we're
going to explore tonight.

769.75.text:
And so the first
thing I want to do

771.21.text:
is go back to that
very first slide,

773.73.text:
and talk about
message number one.

777.27.text:
We are forever changed
through cancer.

781.21.text:
What does it mean to
be forever changed?

783.86.text:
I think our culture
has very little concept

790.50.text:
We are on a very
linear trajectory,

793.32.text:
where you set out something, and
then that's where you're going.

796.76.text:
And people do not
like you to change.

799.63.text:
People also are
not really taught

802.32.text: that death is at all a part.

805.03.text:
Death, leaving, doesn't really
have a place in our culture.

809.67.text:
So if you are touched by that
in any way, shape or form,

817.84.text:
And family and friends
often can't understand why

822.28.text: we don't come back to normal.

823.62.text:
And I hear this all the time--
people saying, you know,

825.91.text:
my yoga group is the
only place where I

827.91.text: can feel like I'm really heard.

830.35.text:
Or I'm going to my support
group, and they get it,

833.45.text: but my old friends still don't.

838.53.text:
that I get back to be normal,
and I just cannot do it.

843.59.text:
So in a way, there is, like,
a death that we're grieving.

847.36.text:
We're grieving our old self,
which we may or may not

850.47.text:
be as fully, or we are
inhabiting our lives

856.75.text:
And then there is the
death that our parents,

859.18.text:
that our lovers,
sometimes our children,

862.88.text:
experience in us having changed,
if they're not ready to give up

871.82.text:
And I think, just
as an example of how

876.27.text:
it used to be, when we were
living a little bit more

882.48.text:
there was more of a
sense that you are moving

884.82.text:
through certain
phases in your life,

886.63.text:
and that they were acknowledged
within your community,

891.05.text:
That, for example, young
boys at a certain age,

894.00.text:
when they were ready
for initiation--

896.34.text:
young boys were taken
from their mothers' homes,

900.27.text: and they were dragged, at night.

902.04.text:
There were men, sometimes
they would be in masks,

904.26.text:
and they would drag the
boy away from the hut.

906.22.text:
And the mothers would wail,
and say, don't take him.

909.45.text:
And then they would go
on their little ritual,

911.62.text:
and they would come
back, days later.

913.61.text:
And the boy had a new
standing in the village,

916.25.text:
and the mothers had
done their grieving.

918.30.text:
And from that moment
on, that young man

920.20.text:
was carrying a new name,
and living in a new way,

924.25.text:
acknowledged by everybody
that they were a new person.

928.59.text: We've lost that in our culture.

930.98.text:
It's not a concept that
is familiar anymore.

937.72.text:
So I want to use this
concept, called the Four

942.65.text:
Shields of Human Nature, to
talk about the different gifts

946.16.text:
and challenges in each of
our pieces of ourselves.

951.76.text:
So the four shields-- without
going into a lot of detail,

955.76.text:
they're basically
like a road map.

957.77.text:
They're coming from some of
the old traditional medicine

961.88.text:
wheels that have
tracked changes in life

965.66.text:
for indigenous cultures
for a very long time.

969.52.text:
And these have been
handed down to me

971.28.text:
from my esteemed teachers,
Steven and Meredith Little,

975.48.text: from the School of Lost Borders.

978.58.text:
So I'm using this
model just to speak

982.23.text:
to changes in our body,
psyche, mind, and spirit,

986.55.text:
and in the model of we
call a becomingness.

990.14.text:
So not just who we
were, who we are now,

992.78.text: or who we're going to be.

993.84.text:
But that we are truly
always moving, and evolving,

1001.13.text:
The first one that I want to
talk about is the South Shield.

1004.24.text:
And I tried to get you an
image that really evokes it,

1007.87.text:
without me having to
talk a lot about it.

1012.89.text:
So you can really feel
into that little girl,

1017.44.text:
running through the grass
at the height of summer.

1024.11.text:
That's our instinctual
self, when it's really well.

1028.70.text:
That's the place that we
all have in ourselves.

1031.37.text:
That little child that loves
to play, that is very fluid.

1035.59.text:
That's why the
element we put with it

1037.27.text:
is water-- the sense of being,
very fluid, being very open,

1041.50.text:
being very in touch
with our senses.

1049.69.text:
So you can imagine
yourselves like this,

1055.14.text:
and what happened to
your self's shield

1058.61.text:
when you've got the
diagnosis of cancer.

1064.91.text:
And the very first challenge
in the South-- the way

1071.09.text:
that the body
reacts to any trauma

1074.46.text: is a fight, flight, and freeze.

1077.12.text:
So that's really what
most of us go through,

1082.94.text:
But even later on, once
we're in survivorship,

1091.27.text:
sometimes we call it violence
in an innocent world.

1095.18.text:
It's like the sense that
something could happen to you.

1098.58.text:
That you are just
not like you were.

1101.41.text:
It's, like, the Garden of
Eden isn't intact anymore.

1106.15.text:
And so a lot of us deal
with anxiety that comes up,

1111.58.text:
fear that gets heightened
sometimes, by the next scan,

1114.83.text:
or the next whatever it is,
symptoms that come up randomly.

1120.27.text: And part of it is that.

1121.72.text:
Part of it is the trauma that
has occurred through cancer,

1126.58.text:
which oftentimes isn't just the
trauma that was just induced

1129.79.text:
by cancer, but also
has this way of poking

1135.60.text:
into anything that was ever
damaged in this health shield.

1139.81.text:
So if you had a childhood
that had a lot of trauma,

1144.23.text:
that will certainly be
revisited in the process

1151.04.text:
So some of the challenges
that we experience

1153.38.text:
in our own instinctual
nature is that sense

1157.56.text:
of trusting our
own instincts, that

1168.35.text: the definition of who we are.

1171.46.text:
Feeling the body's
mortality, and not feeling

1175.34.text:
this feeling of, like,
summer will never end.

1179.72.text:
And so any major change in
health rocks the sense of self.

1185.96.text:
And feeling powerless
is part of that.

1189.54.text:
Sometimes, having doctors and
others act like parents for us

1194.38.text:
Not knowing what to do,
which treatment to pick,

1202.20.text:
There is a safety that
is taken away from us,

1209.20.text: But there are also gifts in it.

1211.02.text:
So a lot of us, through this
process, the other end of it

1215.75.text:
is that we learn to turn
into what our body needs.

1220.68.text:
And eventually, as we
are working ourselves

1225.63.text:
to trust that little
voice inside that

1229.83.text:
Part of it is because
we really need to.

1232.10.text:
We cannot, often, come out of
treatment buffering the way

1237.96.text:
We have to take care of
ourselves in a different way.

1240.84.text:
We have create a new
relationship with ourselves.

1244.01.text:
Some people call it
flowing with the river,

1251.66.text:
Recovering some sense
of our innate goodness

1254.19.text:
in our belonging, maybe
having less responsibilities,

1258.43.text:
and letting ourselves off
the hook a little bit more.

1261.31.text:
Mary Oliver calls it, "letting
the soft animal of your body

1271.65.text:
more able to actually
give ourselves

1273.97.text:
that, than a lot of people that
are just adults, and don't take

1280.12.text:
as good care of their own inner
fluidity and instinctual self.

1287.73.text:
So that brings us
to the West Shield.

1290.69.text: And the West Shield is dark.

1296.45.text:
It's, as we can see,
the fall from Eden.

1301.54.text:
So it really is where
the hero's journey

1303.86.text:
lies, where we face our
fears, and go through what

1307.92.text: I call the dark night of soul.

1312.14.text:
It's the place of turning
our intent, our attention,

1317.74.text: to who I think I really am.

1322.19.text:
So in the South, it's more like
whatever my parents tell me.

1327.51.text:
In the West is the
investigation of,

1329.88.text: what does it really mean for me?

1332.04.text:
So making our own meaning, in
our soul and in our psyche,

1338.35.text:
And oftentimes, in both
treatment and survivorship,

1342.95.text:
we go really, really
down into that darkness.

1348.07.text:
And we ponder the big
questions of our lives

1351.02.text:
there, in a way that not
a lot of people get to do.

1356.38.text:
And in a way that oftentimes
doesn't really sound very easy.

1362.70.text:
I know, for myself,
that I came up

1366.53.text:
with some of those really bare
bones, deep questions that

1370.44.text:
were related to my own psyche,
that I didn't know I had.

1375.48.text:
Things like, feeling
that somehow I

1380.21.text:
That I am somehow
bad, that there's

1385.67.text:
And again, none
of these feelings

1387.22.text: were really that new to me.

1389.59.text:
But they really became
part of my awareness,

1392.99.text: once I was walking with cancer.

1396.23.text:
So I would put here,
also, evaluations

1401.02.text: of how to sit with change.

1405.11.text: How to sit with grief and loss.

1409.37.text:
How to turn into who
I am now, and what I

1412.54.text:
really want to do with this
one precious, wild life.

1417.80.text:
A deep questioning of core
values-- and the gifts that

1422.58.text:
are in that, is that we really
get to individuate in this way.

1428.66.text:
That by asking these
deep questions,

1431.80.text:
there is a new meaning, that
we are oftentimes finding

1436.16.text: some kind of gift in the wound.

1439.00.text:
And we're often finding
that we are like Phoenix,

1444.84.text:
Sometimes, people use
cancer to shed things

1450.46.text:
Whether it be a profession,
a relationship that

1454.60.text:
needed to shift, or
simply their way of taking

1461.95.text:
So there is finding
our true voice,

1465.42.text:
and our authentic
beingness in here.

1468.21.text:
And letting die away
whatever no longer serves.

1472.02.text:
One of the beautiful things is
that we cannot afford anymore

1476.11.text:
to drag baggage along with
us that we'd be better off

1482.32.text:
So the West Shield is giving us
a chance to actually shed that.

1492.58.text:
So we're coming into
the North, and that's

1497.38.text:
And it's really the
adult stage of our lives,

1501.87.text:
and in a lot of ways, I
feel that survivorship

1506.20.text: is very strong in the North.

1514.14.text:
arising out of cancer, is
that we cannot do it alone,

1518.78.text:
that it takes a village,
that it takes support.

1522.50.text:
And there is an incredible
support that gets created,

1526.02.text:
and an incredible
way of community

1528.21.text:
that gets created, some of
which we can feel tonight.

1533.36.text:
There is a thread that
we have with people

1536.99.text:
that have been through
what we've been through.

1539.87.text:
So in the North, we put
ourselves back together,

1544.38.text:
And sometimes, that means
in a very responsible way--

1550.67.text:
It could be decisions
about a living will.

1554.32.text:
It could be decisions
about a job.

1556.74.text:
It could be decisions about
putting your affairs in order.

1563.71.text:
that comes together, that comes
from a place of wholeness,

1567.77.text:
and really having turned into
whatever challenge is there.

1571.98.text:
So it's a sense of accepting
the greater picture,

1577.06.text:
and putting our best foot
forward, and making the life

1582.38.text:
We often say that this shield
is the place in ourselves where

1587.47.text:
we air ourselves, where we
make decisions about what is

1592.24.text: good for us, and what it's not.

1594.56.text:
So any new practices,
that you have brought out

1598.01.text:
in survivorship to help
you support yourself,

1602.20.text:
Like, whether you have a yoga
practice, or a different diet,

1606.22.text:
or whatever it is that
you've decided to do,

1611.96.text:
you have to make that decision
to stick to that practice.

1614.61.text:
If you just let yourself be
swept away by how great it is,

1618.85.text:
you might do it three days,
and not go any further with it.

1622.28.text:
But the North Shield is
really like that North Star,

1626.16.text:
And so the gifts, in this way,
are a lot about self-care.

1632.30.text:
And I think there is a very
special kind of self-care

1635.09.text:
that we get to learn,
after having had cancer,

1639.94.text:
or while we're even
still living with cancer.

1643.75.text:
And that is that the
care of others and self

1649.29.text:
That, in order to take
care of everyone else,

1652.34.text:
we need to take
care of ourselves.

1654.60.text:
That by taking
care of ourselves,

1658.98.text:
And so that's really
different, because we

1661.01.text:
get taught a lot about
sacrifice and taking

1665.42.text:
But again, our own wellness is
going to be the focus for us.

1671.23.text:
And in that way,
there's a gift in that,

1674.84.text:
Because we know that the best
favor we can do our children,

1678.92.text:
for example, is to live
as healthily as we can.

1684.41.text:
Because of course,
nobody ever knows.

1686.61.text:
But we know that we don't know,
and that's the difference.

1691.32.text:
So there's the life change
manifestations here.

1694.83.text:
And there's also the place
where the work really begins.

1698.83.text:
It's how can I share
what I brought out

1702.43.text:
from the cancer
journey, and somehow

1704.13.text: be in the world with that?

1705.60.text:
What's the legacy I
want to do for myself?

1707.95.text:
Like, I know for me,
I was stuck in a job

1710.66.text:
that I had outgrown
a long time ago.

1713.03.text:
And once I went through
cancer, I let go.

1717.62.text:
It was very obvious to me that
if I was thinking about dying,

1721.98.text:
if I was realizing
that, indeed, I

1724.48.text:
was going to die-- and
not just one fine day--

1726.62.text:
but I needed to put my
life where my heart was.

1731.31.text: That was really important to me.

1733.64.text:
So oftentimes, really,
cancer is a chance for us

1738.22.text:
to find the pebble that's in
our shoe, wherever that is,

1741.43.text: and to set our life straight.

1749.29.text:
So it's not so much
if we're going to die.

1752.11.text:
The conversation of
if we're going to die

1753.82.text:
moves to when
we're going to die.

1761.44.text:
But we start being
more concerned

1762.95.text:
about how death is
going to find us.

1765.03.text:
How much are we going to have
made peace with our lives?

1768.93.text:
How fully will we
have lived our lives?

1772.43.text:
And it gives us an
incredible courage

1775.26.text:
to step forward and
do some of the things

1777.26.text:
that we would have never dared
to dream about, otherwise.

1791.23.text:
So we're going back
to message number

1793.42.text:
two-- and that's that we're
in a lifelong path to healing

1797.52.text:
And so that's part of what
I've already spoken to.

1802.58.text:
And I just want to say
that one of the things

1808.04.text:
that I often use
as a metaphor is

1811.69.text:
that when we turn into
our healing after cancer,

1817.44.text:
it's as if we move from
the practice of our living

1820.29.text:
to the practice of
our living and dying.

1825.85.text:
There is a sense, somehow,
that they belong together.

1829.52.text:
And that because we have
a foot in each world,

1833.55.text:
life becomes very
precious to us.

1836.98.text:
And so it depends on-- there
are times in our lives,

1842.74.text:
And then there are, other times,
where we really revel in it.

1845.93.text:
We can have it let us set
free, in a lot of ways.

1849.75.text:
And in other ways,
sometimes, we can

1852.21.text:
let us also sit in the
depth, and darkness,

1857.49.text:
We certainly can't have the
sense of safety back, that we

1862.19.text:
may have had, and confidence
that our body will not fail us,

1868.42.text:
that other people might
still be walking around with.

1872.20.text:
And yet, we have a kind
of a courage and a chance,

1875.74.text:
when the moment that
we're diagnosed,

1877.86.text:
all the way until
we, one fine day,

1881.76.text:
make dying our
greatest healing yet.

1884.94.text:
Anyway, that's the trajectory
that I'm heading for.

1889.46.text:
All the way, in
between those two,

1891.46.text:
I have time to live the
life that I was here

1894.58.text:
to live, and to
give, and to receive.

1897.76.text:
And that is a precious
gift that we all share,

1904.39.text:
because we are initiated
through cancer.

1911.01.text:
And I want to bring it
around to-- I've already kind

1914.06.text:
of feel myself going over

1917.40.text:
is what we call the spring, and

1923.53.text:
And a lot of people now talk

1928.53.text:
So that's basically what

1931.08.text:
Some of the healing impulse

1935.75.text:
and opening to the
mystery of life.

1937.69.text:
And getting some kind
of an understanding,

1940.91.text:
from the depths
of our surrender,

1943.86.text:
of the beauty that surrounds
us, and the preciousness

1947.26.text: of this life, of this moment.

1950.23.text:
No matter what's tomorrow, but
here-- right here, right now.

1954.84.text:
Any kind of big
realizations that we get,

1957.42.text:
that feel kind of,
like, our download.

1961.67.text:
It's the place
where we realize--

1963.29.text:
or the moments in
between-- where

1965.39.text:
we realize that all but love

1970.48.text:
It's that light that
really partners the dark.

So in a way, our edges

1979.86.text:
But also, our light
is a lot brighter.

Our spirit light
shines a lot brighter.

It's almost like we know

Whatever you want to equate that

where there's a

2002.13.text:
and amuse, and juiciness

2010.01.text:
where you feel
like you're getting

2018.33.text:
And so that brings
me to message number

2019.96.text:
three, which is that we are
all elders, no matter our age.

2023.12.text:
And I think that sometimes
is really challenging for us.

2025.92.text:
Especially for the younger
ones of us, that get diagnosed,

2030.28.text:
They go through this
whole initiation process.

2032.95.text:
And we live in a
society, again, where

2034.75.text:
we have a lot of old people
that are just old, that they're

2040.73.text:
So eldering means having been
to the center of your wheel,

2045.50.text:
having looked into the
depth of your own shadow,

2048.82.text:
having swam around
your own cauldron,

2052.27.text:
and come back out
into the light.

2056.04.text:
And the younger we are,
the more challenging

2058.44.text: it is to live with eldering.

2060.53.text:
A lot of the effects of
cancer and survivorship--

2063.72.text:
while they're in
treatment it's, like,

2066.67.text:
the effects are
debilitating, a lot of times.

2071.62.text:
But later on, in
survivorship, a lot

2074.23.text:
of the effects
post-treatment are actually

2079.26.text:
So that includes anything and
everything, from constipation,

2083.82.text:
to sleeplessness, to
menopause, to you name it.

2089.16.text:
All the different
things, and then

2090.70.text:
all the different risks
of other diseases,

2095.96.text:
And not for nothing, when we
come back from chemotherapy,

2099.52.text:
most of us have very white
hair, slowly turning into gray.

2103.73.text:
And then slowly, if we're lucky,
recovering our regular color,

2108.83.text:
There's a sense of really being
pushed towards our eldering.

2113.64.text:
And I think we often just think
that that's a terrible thing.

2116.77.text:
It's like, oh God, I'm going
to grow older early now, too.

2120.52.text:
But there is not just the
faster aging of our bodies.

2127.60.text:
is also turning
stronger and stronger.

2131.21.text:
So again, because we can hold
both of these paradigms--

2135.07.text:
not just the challenge,
but also the gift--

2141.53.text:
If you watch a person that
is an elder, an old elder--

2145.88.text:
somebody who is of, say,
importance in their community--

2150.43.text:
they often have a
lightness to themselves.

2153.05.text:
They don't carry a lot
of baggage anymore.

2155.50.text:
They've made their way around
their own wheel of life.

2159.93.text:
They've made it good
with their choices.

2161.80.text:
They have put their
affairs in order.

2164.16.text:
Now they can just
live with a lightness

2166.50.text:
and an open-heartedness that
we all so need around us.

2172.42.text:
And so those are all
things that are open to us,

2180.07.text:
And there is a regular movement
in our eldering, I think,

2187.25.text:
It just gets sped
up through cancer.

2193.35.text:
Sometimes I call this a
decision to steward our lives,

2198.69.text:
You know, there's
a lightness to it.

2200.19.text:
There's not so much the
selfishness that's driving us.

2204.42.text:
And even the service of
others isn't driving us

2208.45.text:
in the same way
that it was before.

2210.12.text:
It comes more from a
place of ease, than

2218.49.text:
Something about living in
grace, and in gratitude

2226.45.text:
So I want to finish this with a
quote, and a couple more shots,

2230.42.text:
before I take some of your
questions, if you have any.

2234.32.text:
"Those who contemplate
the beauty of the earth

2236.88.text:
find reserves of
strengths that will

2238.65.text: endure as long as life lasts.

2243.00.text:
in the repeated
refrains of nature--

2245.01.text:
the assurance that
dawn comes after night,

2250.19.text:
And that I would add,
that as much as life

2254.03.text:
is not permanent, which is
the big lesson that we all

2257.13.text:
learn when we get cancer,
death also is not permanent.

2261.82.text:
There's a real sense of,
for me, oftentimes nature

2265.72.text:
is the place where I go
because it is not linear.

2269.64.text:
Because somehow, when I'm
on the earth, I can be held.

2272.77.text:
It's big enough to hold
my entire spectrum--

2276.32.text:
the dark, the light, and
everything in between,

2281.71.text:
So we are not off
the map as survivors.

2286.44.text:
We are in the map
of our humanness,

2288.85.text:
and we're living it, I
believe, in a fuller way.

2291.66.text:
And we're asked to step into
ourselves in a fuller way.

2297.74.text:
No matter what our
prognosis is, it's not about

2301.02.text: whether we are healthy, or not.

2302.60.text:
Because as we all know,
that shifts, right?

2304.86.text: You can be a survivor today.

2306.84.text:
You could have a
recurrence tomorrow.

2308.89.text:
And you can have Stage
4 something today,

2311.76.text: and you can be healthy tomorrow.

2313.88.text:
And there is no defining
ourselves that way, any longer.

2319.14.text:
So we find ourselves, our
strength and our humanness,

2328.41.text:
I do-- I lead some
programs in nature.

2333.59.text:
We're finding ways to be out

2339.19.text:
And here's a picture
from our last group.

2345.01.text:
And it's usually to mark

2349.12.text:
and to use that time in

2354.72.text:
And if you're
interested in that,

2356.09.text:
I have a little
flier here, that I

2357.73.text: think Holly has some copies of.

2359.72.text:
So you can pick some

2369.04.text:
And I hope this made

What do you say to people,

your treatments are finished,

Is there a way of putting

2412.57.text:
putting that into
a talking point?

2419.44.text:
I'm going to repeat

2421.50.text:
Because they told me I had
to, so that they get it

2426.45.text:
So what do I say to
somebody, when they ask me,

2430.23.text: And so are you OK now?

2433.58.text: Can we move past this now?

2435.21.text: Can we move past this now?

2436.70.text:
You know, I sometimes
say to people,

2440.71.text:
do you want to do
you want to have

2442.17.text:
the two-sentence answer, the
two-minute, or the two-hour?

2446.61.text: Like, I try to push them back.

2448.91.text:
Because most people really
don't want to deal with it.

2451.28.text:
They want to just have
you say, yeah, I'm OK.

2454.39.text:
And it's a way to
really stand our ground,

2456.69.text: and say no, I'm not OK.

2459.19.text:
And without so many
words, but energetically,

2462.01.text:
really, what you're
saying to them is like,

2464.01.text: you don't want to face this.

2466.70.text: But I'm not going to go away.

2470.02.text:
If you can't deal with

2473.99.text: So it's obviously not that easy.

2476.63.text:
But what I want to do, is

2480.79.text:
having to say what
they want to hear--

2484.49.text:
to say very-- and depending
on who it is-- is it really

2489.86.text:
Because sometimes, we get

2492.84.text: kind of ride on our misfortune.

2494.99.text:
They have that look about--
like, I feel so sorry for you.

2499.65.text:
I hope you're
going to be OK now.

2501.15.text:
And it just feels like, oh,

2509.87.text: So there is all sorts of people.

And I think the

2513.19.text:
is that it's really
important to create

2518.82.text:
You get to be who
you are, and you

can show yourself as much as the

2526.47.text:
So we say sometimes,
in our work,

And I know that's

on your website,

Stanford will host the talk,

as well, hopefully--

I'm coming up to four years

But there is a book by a

2564.20.text: of Santa Clara, my alma mater.

Some people don't just

And I published a book that

2591.96.text:
You know-- dying

because it makes it

And you've talked about

2631.26.text:
You have had some kind of an

2636.66.text:
And the title--

2638.05.text:

2642.68.text:
it's called, the title

2648.28.text:
And the flipside is Words

2651.74.text:
So I really, honestly think

2655.91.text:
see these manifestations

2659.91.text:
You know, the
things-- people take

2661.41.text:
trips they've wanted to

2664.61.text:
People say, I don't care

2669.22.text:
Whatever it is, it

2673.53.text:
What matters is that we

2677.01.text:
of this one precious life,
and we remember ourselves

2681.66.text:
Like you said, like your book

2702.75.text:
I have a question, and I'm
sure all of us have it.

2705.18.text:
It's that little,
tiny voice, sometimes,

2707.46.text:
you get in the back
of your head-- like,

2711.30.text:
I mean, everybody-- we all go
through our day-to-day things.

2714.11.text:
But it's always that
little, tiny voice.

2715.84.text:
And you can't
really talk about it

2717.78.text:
with the other
people in your life,

2721.49.text: So how do we all deal with that?

2726.95.text:
So the question
was, how do we deal

2729.49.text:
with our fear, that little voice
inside, that says, oh my God--

2733.59.text:
what if I'm going
to get a recurrence?

2737.55.text:
I think-- so the question was,
how do we all deal with that?

2741.20.text:
And I think the biggest thing
is to lose the illusion that we

2746.39.text:
We think, oh, I'm going
to outgrow that voice.

2748.95.text:
Or I'm going to-- and to
a certain degree, yeah.

2750.95.text:
That voice will go
through changes,

2752.49.text:
and there will be days
where it's not there.

2754.66.text:
And there will be other
days where it's there.

2756.64.text:
They'll be the little
headaches sneaking in.

2760.95.text:
I think the hardest part is
to be gentle with ourselves,

2764.49.text:
and to truly know that
this is our own fear.

2768.88.text:
It is that trauma, and we have
to parent it in ourselves.

2775.89.text:
Not to make it
wrong, not to push it

2778.18.text:
away, but to just over and over,
say, yes, I know this is hard.

2785.74.text:
And there are times--
I can tell for myself,

2788.51.text:
that there are times I'm really
flying high in my survivorship.

2791.70.text:
And there are other times
where I get really anxious,

2795.36.text:
and I have periods--
I don't know why.

2797.70.text:
I can't explain
them, where I have

2800.01.text:
a lot of what I call
post-traumatic stress disorder.

2803.05.text:
Nobody wants to name it that,
but I think we all have it.

2806.82.text:
And so again, there's power
in acknowledging what's here,

2811.11.text:
I think, as we work with
it, at some point we

2813.99.text: don't identify with it as much.

2816.53.text:
But we learn how
to partner it more.

2819.36.text:
And I think it's a
lifelong learning path.

2822.38.text:
And we don't get to
go off of our pillow.

2827.16.text: We have to face that mirror.

2828.45.text:
We have to face that
wall, whatever it is.

2832.57.text:
And the truth is there isn't
any knowing for anyone,

2835.53.text: but we are living on the edge.

2838.12.text:
But because of that,
like the gentleman said,

2840.47.text:
we're also living on the edge
of our becoming, all the time.

2847.61.text:
But I think-- and
just one more thing.

2850.15.text:
So the thing is, really,
that we can't go back.

2854.01.text:
And I think we suffer more when
we try to be where we're not,

2858.57.text: or who we are not anymore.

2862.74.text:
It's like, if whatever we've
lost, that in our new life

2870.38.text:
But if we can celebrate
what is here now,

2872.61.text:
that wasn't available to us
before, then that's oftentimes
